problems.title: Number Theory - n^7 - n is divisible by 42
problems.problem: Show that $n^7 - n$ is divisible by $42$ for every positive integer $n$.
problems.hint:
• A number is divisible by $42$ if it is divisible by $6$ and $7$.
  • Use Fermat's Little Theorem to show that it is divisible by $7$.
problems.solution:
Note that a number is divisible by $42$ if it is divisible by $7$ and $6$, that is, divisible by $7,2$ and $3$. Now we have \begin{align*} n^7 - n & = n(n^6 - 1) = n ((n^2)^3 - 1) \\ & = n (n^2 - 1)(n^4 + n^2 + 1) \\ & = n (n-1)(n+1) (n^4 + n^2 + 1). \end{align*} Since the product any three consecutive integers is divisible by $6$, so $n^7 - n$ is divisible by $6$.
To show that it is divisible by $7$, we will use Fermat's Little Theorem. By Fermat's Little Theorem, \[ n^7 \equiv n \ (\mathrm{mod}\ 7) \implies 7 \mid (n^7 - n). \] Therefore, the number $n^7 - n$ is divisible by $42$.

problems.title: Probability - The function fx) = 6x (1 - x) is a probability density function
problems.problem:
The diameter of an electric cable, say $X$ is assumed to be a continuous random variable with probability density function (pdf)
    \[
        f(x) = 6x (1 - x), \quad 0 \leq x\leq 1.
    \]
    Check that above is a pdf and determine a number $b$ such that $P(X < b) = P(X > b)$.
problems.hint:
• $f$ is pdf if $\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } f(x) \mathrm{d} x = 1$.
  • $P(X< b) = \int_0^b f(x) \mathrm{d} x$ and $P(x > b) = \int_b^1 f(x) \mathrm{d} x$.
problems.solution:
To see if the given function is a pdf or not, we will check if the total probability is $1$. That is, \begin{align*} \int_{-\infty }^ \infty f(x) \mathrm{d} x = 1. \end{align*} Note that, \begin{align*} \int_{-\infty }^ \infty f(x) \mathrm{d} x & \int_0^1 f(x) \mathrm{d} x \\ & = 6\int_0^1 x(1-x) \mathrm{d} x \\ & = 6 \int _0^1 (x - x^2) \mathrm{d} x \\ & = 6 \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} - \frac{x^3}{3} \right]_0^1 \\ & = 1. \end{align*}
Given that $P(X < b) = P(X > b)$, we have \begin{align*} & \int_0^b f(x) \mathrm{d} x = \int_b^1 f(x) \mathrm{d} x \\ \implies & 6 \int_0^b (x(1-x)) = 6 \int_1^b (x(1-x)) \\ \implies & \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} - \frac{x^3}{3} \right]_0^b = \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} - \frac{x^3}{3} \right]_b^1 \\ \implies & \left( \frac{b^2}{2} - \frac{b^3}{3} \right) = \left[ \left( \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{3} \right) - \left( \frac{b^2}{2} - \frac{b^3}{3} \right) \right] \\ \implies & 3b^2 - 2b^3 = 1 - 3b^2 + 2b^3 \\ \implies & 4b^3 - 6b^2 + 1 = 0 \\ \implies & (2b -1)(2b^2 - 2b - 1) = 0 \\ \implies & 2b - 1 = 0, \quad \text{ since } 2b^2 - 2b - 1 >0. \end{align*} Thus $b = \frac{1}{2}$.

problems.title: NBHM - Find the value of a in x^3 - 5x^2 + ax - 1
problems.problem:
Find the value of $a \in \mathbb{Z} $ such that $2 + \sqrt{3} $ is a root of the polynomial 
    \[
        p(x) = x^3 - 5x^2 + ax - 1.
    \]
problems.hint:
• The irrational roots are in conjugate pairs.
  • Apply ratioanl root theorem.
problems.solution: By ratioanl root theorem, the only possible rational roots are $\pm 1$. Also, since the polynomial is with integer coefficients, any irrational root will be in pair (with its conjugate). Therefore the possible roots are \[ \{ 2 + \sqrt{3} , 2 - \sqrt{3} , 1 \} \quad \text{ or } \{ 2 + \sqrt{3} , 2 - \sqrt{3} , -1 \}. \] Recall that the sum of roots of a polynomial \[ a_n x^n + a_{n-1} x^{n-1} + \dots + a_1 x + a_0, \] is $-\frac{a_{n-1} }{a_n}$. So in our case it is $5$. Therefore the roots are $\{ 2 + \sqrt{3} , 2 - \sqrt{3} , 1 \}.$ Therefore, \begin{align*} a & = (2 + \sqrt{3} ) (2 - \sqrt{3} ) + (2 + \sqrt{3} )(1) + (2-\sqrt{3} )(1) \\ & = (4 -3) + 2 + \sqrt{3} + 2 - \sqrt{3} \\ & = 5. \end{align*} Thus, $a = 5$.

problems.title: Calculus - NBHM - 2005 - div(curl(v)) = 0
problems.problem:
Let $\mathbf{v} = (v_1, v_2. v_3)$ be a vector field on $\mathbb{R} ^3$ where
    \[
        v_1 = \sqrt{1 + x^2 + y^2} , v_2 = \sqrt{1+ z^2} \text{ and } v_3 = \sqrt{1+ x^2 y^2 z^2}.
    \]
    Evaluate $\mathrm{div} (\mathrm{curl}(\mathbf{v} ) )$.
problems.hint: • Recall that if the components of a vector field have continuous second-order partial derivatives, then $\mathrm{div}(\mathrm{curl}(\mathbf{v})) = 0$.
problems.solution:
The curl of a vector field $\mathbf{v} = (v_1,v_2,v_3)$ is given by \[ \nabla \times \mathbf{v} = \left( \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial z}, \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial y} \right). \]
Taking the divergence, we obtain \begin{align*} \nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{v}) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \left( \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial z} \right) + \frac{\partial}{\partial y} \left( \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial v_3}{\partial x} \right) + \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \left( \frac{\partial v_2}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial v_1}{\partial y} \right) \\[0.5em] &= \frac{\partial^2 v_3}{\partial x \partial y} - \frac{\partial^2 v_2}{\partial x \partial z} + \frac{\partial^2 v_1}{\partial y \partial z} - \frac{\partial^2 v_3}{\partial y \partial x} + \frac{\partial^2 v_2}{\partial z \partial x} - \frac{\partial^2 v_1}{\partial z \partial y}. \end{align*} Since the functions $v_1, v_2,$ and $v_3$ have continuous second-order partial derivatives on $\mathbb{R}^3$, the mixed partial derivatives commute: \[ \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y} = \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}. \] Hence, each pair of terms cancels, and we conclude that \[ \nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{v}) = 0. \] Therefore, \[ \boxed{\mathrm{div}(\mathrm{curl}(\mathbf{v})) = 0.} \]

problems.title: NBHM 2005 - Find the area of the triangle
problems.problem: What is the area of the triangle in the complex plane formed by the points representing $1, \omega $ and $\omega ^2$, where $\omega $ is a complex cube root of unity?
problems.hint: • Draw picture and note that it is an equilateral triangle.
problems.solution:
We need to find the area of the triangle formed by the points representing $1, \omega $ and $\omega ^2$. The triangle is equilateral triangle and the side length is \begin{align*} \left\vert 1 - \omega \right\vert^2 = \left\vert \left( \frac{3}{2} \right)^2 + \left( \frac{-\sqrt{3} }{2} \right)^2 \right\vert = 3. \end{align*}
Thus, the side length is $\sqrt{3} $. Therefore, the area of the triangle will be \begin{align*} A & = \frac{\sqrt{3} }{4} (\text{ side } ^2) = \frac{\sqrt{3} }{4} (\sqrt{3} ^2) = \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{4}. \end{align*}
